summary: Slikey, re: mods breaking with updates
mainText: 'Mods are only affected if we change the underlying system and interference will be mitigated with a deprecation policy. summary: Slikey, re: transfer packet
mainText: 'It has a 4KB payload you can use however you want. We definitely recommend to use an HMAC message if you want to transmit trustable data. It also contains the referrer so you can see which server sent the client. Additionally we are making the destination an array now in case the transfer doesn't work so that you can add fallbacks.'

summary: Slikey, re: joining your friends' worlds
mainText: 'Yep! We have a video in the making to show your how it works. Right now I can go into my single player, click Online Play in the ESC menu and share a code to my friend. The friend uses to code to join me in my singleplayer world. You can also rent a server from a hosting provider but for a simple coop you can just use our singleplayer friend join.'

summary: Slikey, re: ping in Hytale
mainText: 'This is where the transfer packet comes in. On Hypixel network we had to connect you to one of our proxies (BungeeCord) which are all in the US. In Hytale you can connect to a server network and the initial "load balancer" redirects you to a server that is much closer to you. The server can then take ping into account for matchmaking and the more distributed they are, the better the average ping for players.'

summary: Slikey, re: players not manually installing mods when they join a modded world/server
mainText: 'This is a core part of Hytale modding strategy. The server is at the core of modding and you will never have to download any mods to play on a modded server. We want the mods to be seamless. When you connect to your friends single player or to a multi-player server: You automatically download all mods required to play. summary: Slikey, re: console support requiring maintaining a renderer per platform
mainText: 'And that is exactly why we make the game good first before touching other platforms. The effort is high and we are highly dedicated to first make this game great on PC. Once we have dug ourselves out of that the project's history, we can look at the horizon with a strong identity that allows us to not get lost chasing platforms and bigger features.'

summary: Slikey, re: using Vulkan
mainText: 'Just Vulkan wouldn't cut it. Vulkan isn't supported on the XBOX (DX12) or PS5 (Gnm). MoltenVK has been Open-Sourced recently, so that is an option to combine VK and Metal. Overall there isn't a silver bullet that doesn't involve some sort of higher level abstraction, which often has it's own issues too. https://ravbug.com/graphics/'

summary: Slikey, re: using OpenGL for Mac
mainText: 'That's why we target OpenGL 4.1 at the moment. Apple deprecated support but didn't drop it. So we have MacOS support without having to do the heavy lifting of going Metal / MoltenVK yet.'

summary: Slikey, re: hypothetically using Steam's Fex translation layer instead of making native port for every platform
mainText:
'The complication isn't necessarily the inability to compile for these platforms. We can compile for these targets but it involves so much more to reach these platforms.
1. Graphics: We currently have a renderer based on OpenGL 3.3 / 4.1. Mobile devices usually use Vulkan or OpenGL ES. We plan to support to Vulkan / Metal / DX12 for PC Platform reason (e.g. async buffer writes) anyway, so we want to wait for that.
2. UI / UX: Playing a game on phones is vastly different to keyboard+mouse / gamepad. The screensize is much smaller, network connection is limitted, battery power is most limitted, touch controls, etc.
3. Compliance / Store Integration: Any phone target also comes with drastic differences in our ability to service patches, feature rollouts, payment methods, etc. 

Overall this is something that is quite a bit more than just x86 vs arm. We are targetting arm64 anyway with our builds for native MacOS M1+ support, so FEX doesn't really solve anything for us.'
